overview.heading: Overview
overview.intro: The Necessary Reunions project reunites historical maps and textual sources from the Dutch East India Company (VOC) archives to reconceptualise Kerala's early modern topography. This documentation provides comprehensive guidance on using the three main tools developed for this project.
overview.rechartedDesc: An IIIF viewer and editor for browsing and annotating 30 historical Kerala maps from various archives, including the Leupe collection at the National Archives in The Hague.
overview.gavocTitle: GAVOC (Grote Atlas van de Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie)
overview.gavocDesc: A historical place name database with over 11,000 standardised entries linking historical and modern names with coordinates and categories, serving as a reference dataset for external linking.
overview.gazetteerDesc: A searchable interface for exploring places located on the 30 maps in re:Charted, showing the history and transitions of places in the Kerala region.
overview.feature1: Web-based and free to use for researchers worldwide
overview.feature2: IIIF manifest support for standardised image delivery
overview.feature3: SVG annotation capabilities for precise map markup
overview.feature4: Integration between annotations and historical place names
overview.feature5: Public API for external linking and data integration
overview.feature6: Open source codebase hosted on GitHub
overview.feature7: Multi-project support for different research collections
overview.whyText: Historical maps and documents from the VOC tell richer stories when brought back together. The project reunites cartographic and textual sources that were separated by time and archival practice, enabling new insights into early modern Kerala's geography, economy, and society. By making these connections visible and searchable, researchers can trace how places were understood, named, and represented across different sources and time periods.

gettingStarted.heading: Getting Started
gettingStarted.intro: All three tools are accessible directly through your web browser at <link>necessaryreunions.org</link>. No installation or account creation is required for viewing and exploring the data.
gettingStarted.step1Text: Navigate to the homepage and select the tool that fits your research needs. Use re:Charted for map exploration, GAVOC for place name research, or Gazetteer for quick searches.
gettingStarted.step2Text: Each tool has an intuitive interface designed for researchers. Hover over buttons and interface elements for tooltips explaining their function.
gettingStarted.step3Title: Step 3: Use Search and Filter Functions
gettingStarted.step3Text: All tools support searching by historical or modern place names. Use filters to narrow down results by category, time period, or geographic region.
gettingStarted.accessingDataText: All data created in the scope of this project will eventually be part of the larger <globaliseLink>GLOBALISE project</globaliseLink>. The code is freely available on <githubLink>GitHub</githubLink>, and the data can be accessed via public APIs.

recharted.heading: re:Charted: IIIF Map Viewer and Editor
recharted.intro: re:Charted is an IIIF (International Image Interoperability Framework) viewer and editor specifically designed for viewing and annotating historical Kerala maps from the VOC archives. The tool provides comprehensive functionality for browsing maps, viewing AI-generated annotations, and creating new annotations with linking to external gazetteers.

infoTab.heading: 1. Info Tab: IIIF Viewer Basics
infoTab.intro: The Info tab provides the foundation for navigating historical maps using the IIIF standard. This interface is designed for researchers who need to examine high-resolution digitised maps in detail.
infoTab.pan: Pan: Click and drag to move around the map surface
infoTab.zoom: Zoom: Use scroll wheel or on-screen controls to zoom in/out with deep zoom capabilities
infoTab.rotate: Rotate: Rotate the map view to align with different orientations for easier reading
infoTab.fullScreen: Full Screen: Expand to full-screen mode for immersive examination
infoTab.home: Home: Reset view to default position and zoom level
infoTab.videoDesc: Navigate the IIIF viewer interface and load map manifests

manifest.heading: 2. Manifest: Metadata and Map Information
manifest.intro: Each map in re:Charted is served through an IIIF manifest containing essential metadata. The manifest panel displays comprehensive information about the historical map you are viewing.
manifest.title: Title: Full title of the historical map as recorded in archival sources
manifest.dimensions: Dimensions: Physical size and digital resolution of the map
manifest.source: Source: Archival institution and collection reference (e.g., Leupe collection, National Archives)
manifest.date: Date: Creation date or estimated date range of the map
manifest.attribution: Attribution: Cartographer, draughtsman, or surveyor information when available
manifest.note: This metadata is crucial for proper citation and understanding the historical context of each map. The manifest follows IIIF Presentation API 3.0 standards, ensuring interoperability with other IIIF-compatible tools and viewers.

mapTab.heading: 3. Map Tab: Georeferencing and Modern Overlay
mapTab.intro: The Map tab provides georeferenced overlays that align historical maps with modern geographic coordinates. This powerful feature uses Allmaps and Leaflet to enable spatial comparison between historical and contemporary cartography.
mapTab.videoDesc: Explore georeferenced overlays and adjust map alignment with modern coordinates
mapTab.allmaps: Allmaps Integration: Uses Allmaps georeferencing engine to transform historical map coordinates to modern geographic positions
mapTab.leaflet: Leaflet Base Map: Displays modern OpenStreetMap tiles as reference layer
mapTab.opacity: Adjustable Opacity: Slider control to blend historical and modern maps for visual comparison
mapTab.controlPoints: Control Points: View georeferencing control points that anchor the historical map to modern coordinates
mapTab.accuracy: Transformation Accuracy: Visual indicators showing alignment quality and distortion

viewingMode.heading: 4. Annotation Tab: Viewing Mode
viewingMode.intro: For users who are not signed in, the Annotation tab operates in viewing mode, providing read-only access to all annotations on the map. This mode is ideal for researchers who want to explore existing annotations without editing capabilities.
viewingMode.videoDesc: Browse and filter AI-generated and human-verified annotations
viewingMode.filterIntro: The annotation list shows all annotations for the currently displayed map canvas, organised with multiple filtering options:
viewingMode.aiVsHuman: AI vs Human Verified: Toggle to filter between AI-generated annotations (from MapReader and Loghi) and human-verified annotations that have been reviewed and confirmed
viewingMode.type: Annotation Type: Filter by type (Text Spotting, Iconography, Georeferencing, Linking)
viewingMode.source: Source: Filter by origin (Loghi AI, Other AI, Human)
viewingMode.assessment: Assessment Status: View which annotations have been checked and validated
viewingMode.searchText: Search across all annotation text content to quickly locate specific place names, features, or terms on the map. The search function operates across all annotation types and highlights matching results in the list.
viewingMode.indicatorsIntro: Each annotation in the list displays icons providing quick information about its properties:
viewingMode.linkIcon: Link Icon: Indicates the annotation is part of a linking annotation connecting to geographic location
viewingMode.commentIcon: Comment Icon: Shows annotation has associated comments or notes
viewingMode.classificationIcon: Classification Icon: Displays assigned iconography classification (fort, settlement, ship, etc.)
viewingMode.checkmark: Checkmark Badge: Indicates human verification and assessment status

editingMode.heading: 5. Annotation Tab: Editing Mode
editingMode.intro: For authenticated users with editing permissions, the Annotation tab transforms into a comprehensive annotation workbench. This mode provides complete control over the annotation process, allowing researchers to refine AI-generated annotations, create new annotations, and establish geographic connections.
editingMode.permissionsNote: Edit access is controlled per project. Each project maintains an allowlist of ORCID identifiers. Sign in with your ORCID to verify your editing permissions for each project.
editingMode.flexibleWorkflowText: The editing steps can be performed in any order according to your research workflow. There is no prescribed sequence - annotators can delete incorrect annotations, add new ones, correct existing content, assign classifications, add comments, and create linking annotations as needed for each map.

deletion.heading: 5a. Deletion: Managing Annotations
deletion.intro: Remove incorrect or duplicate annotations to maintain data quality. The deletion function supports both individual and bulk operations for efficient curation.
deletion.videoDesc: Remove individual annotations or perform bulk deletion operations
deletion.single: Single Deletion: Select and delete individual annotations that are incorrect or unnecessary
deletion.bulk: Bulk Deletion: Select multiple annotations using checkboxes and delete them in a single operation
deletion.confirmation: Two-Step Confirmation: First click marks the item, second click confirms removal to prevent accidental deletion
deletion.undo: Undo Support: Recent deletions can be reversed if removed in error
deletion.note: Deletion is particularly useful for removing AI-generated annotations that incorrectly identified map decorations, cartouches, or other non-geographic features as text or icons.

correction.heading: 5b. Correction: Refining Text and Geometry
correction.intro: Correct and refine existing annotations by editing text content and adjusting SVG polygon boundaries. This step improves the accuracy of AI-generated annotations.
correction.videoDesc: Edit text fields and adjust SVG polygon geometry for precise annotation
correction.textField: Text Field Editing: Click to edit annotation text, correcting OCR errors or incomplete transcriptions
correction.svgPolygon: SVG Polygon Adjustment: Drag polygon vertices to precisely match the boundaries of text or iconography on the map
correction.addRemovePoints: Add/Remove Points: Add new vertices to complex shapes or remove unnecessary points for cleaner geometry
correction.livePreview: Live Preview: See changes reflected immediately on the map as you edit
correction.guidelinesIntro: When drawing or correcting SVG polygons, ensure all characters are fully enclosed within the boundary. Zoom in close to verify that polygon edges are near the character edges but do not crop or pass through any part of the letters.
correction.fullCoverage: Full Coverage: All characters must be completely visible within the polygon boundary
correction.tallLetters: Tall Letters: Pay special attention to ascending and descending letters like "f", "p", "g", "y" and capital initials
correction.closeFit: Close Fit: Keep boundaries close to character edges without overlapping the text itself
correction.avoidInclusions: Avoid Inclusions: Try not to include other map elements (icons, borders, other text) within the polygon when possible
correction.standardsNote: These guidelines follow the <link>Machines Reading Maps annotation standards</link>.

addNew.heading: 5c. Add New: Creating Text and Iconography Annotations
addNew.intro: Create new annotations for map features that were not detected by AI systems. This includes both text spotting (place names, labels) and iconography (symbols, icons) annotations.
addNew.videoDesc: Create new text spotting and iconography annotations from scratch
addNew.textSpotting: Text Spotting: Draw a polygon around text on the map and transcribe the content
addNew.iconography: Iconography: Draw a polygon around map symbols, icons, or pictorial elements
addNew.drawingTools: Drawing Tools: Click to create polygon vertices, double-click to complete shape
addNew.metadata: Metadata Entry: Add annotation body content (text transcription or description)
addNew.polygonNote: When drawing new polygons, follow the same coverage guidelines as for corrections: ensure all characters or icon elements are fully enclosed without cropping. Zoom in to verify that polygon boundaries are close to the edges but do not pass through the text or symbols.
addNew.importanceNote: Adding new annotations is essential for capturing map features that AI systems miss, such as faded text, unusual iconography, or symbols in non-standard positions. This human curation ensures comprehensive coverage of all map content.

classification.heading: 5d. Assign Classification: Categorising Iconography
classification.intro: Assign semantic classifications to iconography annotations using a controlled thesaurus of map symbol types. This structured classification enables systematic analysis of map content across the collection.
classification.videoDesc: Categorise iconography annotations using the controlled thesaurus
classification.thesaurus: Thesaurus Selection: Choose from predefined categories (fort, settlement, ship, church, etc.)
classification.hierarchical: Hierarchical Structure: Classifications organised by type and subtype
classification.multiple: Multiple Classifications: Assign multiple categories when a symbol has compound meaning
classification.visual: Visual Consistency: Colour-coded badges show classification in annotation list

commenting.heading: 5e. Comment and Mark: Assessment and Notes
commenting.intro: Add comments to annotations and mark them as assessed to track verification progress. This workflow feature supports collaborative annotation projects where multiple researchers review and validate map content.
commenting.videoDesc: Add comments and mark annotations as checked and verified
commenting.commentField: Comment Field: Add notes about annotation quality, uncertainty, or interpretation
commenting.assessment: Assessment Checkbox: Mark annotations as "checked" after human verification
commenting.history: Annotation History: Track who made comments and when assessments occurred
commenting.qualityControl: Quality Control: Filter views to show only assessed or unassessed annotations
commenting.note: The assessment system is crucial for distinguishing between raw AI output and human-verified data. Researchers can focus their work on unassessed annotations or prioritise reviewing AI-generated content flagged with low confidence scores.

linking.heading: 5f. Link: Creating Geographic Connections
linking.intro: The linking function is the most sophisticated editing feature, creating linking annotations that connect selected text spotting and iconography annotations in a reading order, associate them with external gazetteer entries, and establish geographic positioning on the map.
linking.videoDesc: Link annotations to geographic locations using GAVOC, GLOBALISE, NeRu, Nominatim, or Wikidata
linking.readingOrder: Reading Order: Select multiple text spotting and iconography annotations and arrange them in reading order (e.g., place name text + settlement icon). Numbered badges appear on selected annotations showing their sequence.
linking.geotag: Geotag from Thesaurus: Search and select a matching place from one of five external thesauri:
linking.gavoc: GAVOC: Historical place names database based on the Grote Atlas van de Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie
linking.globalise: GLOBALISE: Historical place names database created by the GLOBALISE project, focussing on the VOC
linking.neru: NeRu: Historical place names database specific to the Kerala region
linking.wikidata: Wikidata: Linked open data place entries from the Wikidata knowledge base
linking.point: Point Placement: Click on the map image to add an x/y coordinate point showing the geographic centre of the place. This point serves multiple purposes:
linking.pointVisual: Visual marker of the place location on the map
linking.pointGeoref: Data for improving georeferencing accuracy in future iterations
linking.pointSpatial: Reference point for spatial analysis of place distribution

interface.heading: Interface Elements
interface.leftPanel: Left Panel: Map collection browser with thumbnails and search
interface.centreViewport: Centre Viewport: Main map viewing area with annotation overlays
interface.rightPanel: Right Panel: Resizable tabbed interface (Info, Manifest, Map, Annotations) - drag the edge to adjust width (320-700px)
interface.topNav: Top Navigation: Project switcher, navigation links, and user authentication

multiProject.heading: Multi-Project Support
multiProject.intro: re:Charted supports multiple research projects, each with its own manuscript collection, annotation repository, and configuration. Use the Project Switcher in the top navigation bar to switch between available projects.
multiProject.neru: Necessary Reunions (NeRu): Historical maps of early modern Kerala from Dutch East India Company archives. Uses the GLOBALISE AnnoRepo instance with GAVOC, GLOBALISE, NeRu, and Nominatim as geotag sources.
multiProject.stm: Suriname Time Machine (STM): Historical maps and documents from the Suriname colonial archive. Uses its own AnnoRepo instance with Nominatim and Wikidata as geotag sources.
multiProject.permissions: Each project has its own editing permissions managed through an ORCID-based allowlist. Authenticated users can only edit annotations in projects they have been granted access to.

sharing.heading: Sharing & URL State
sharing.intro: The viewer URL automatically updates to reflect the current canvas and selected annotation, making it possible to share specific views with colleagues. Use the Share View button in the tab bar to copy a direct link to the current view state (including manifest, canvas, and annotation selection).
sharing.contentState: re:Charted also supports IIIF Content State: paste or drag-and-drop a Content State JSON or URL into the viewer to open a specific manifest and canvas directly.

gavoc.heading: GAVOC: Historical Place Name Database
gavoc.intro: GAVOC (Grote Atlas van de Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie) is a comprehensive database of historical place names from early modern Kerala, containing over 11,000 standardised entries linking historical and modern toponyms with geographic coordinates and semantic categories.
gavoc.citation: The GAVOC database is based on the comprehensive index in: Schilder, Gunter, Jacques Moerman, Ferjan Ormeling, Paul van den Brink and Hans Ferwerda. Grote atlas van de Verenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie. Volume I: Atlas Isaak de Graaf. Voorburg: Asia Maior, 2006. ISBN 9789074861137. [National Archives, The Hague: 2.14.97, inv.nr. 11.1]
gavoc.historicalPlaces: Historical Places: A curated collection of place names from Dutch East India Company maps and documents
gavoc.entries: 11,000+ Standardised Entries: Each entry cleaned, verified, and structured for research use
gavoc.metadata: Comprehensive Metadata: Historical names, modern equivalents, coordinates, and semantic categories
gavoc.reference: Reference Dataset: Serves as the authoritative linking target for annotations in re:Charted
gavoc.persistentUris: Persistent URIs: Each place has a unique, citable identifier for long-term scholarly reference
gavoc.videoDesc: Navigate the GAVOC interface, search for historical place names, and explore the map and table views
gavoc.originalName: Historical place name as it appears on the map
gavoc.category: Type of location (settlement, bay, island, region, etc.)
gavoc.mapGridSquare: Location reference on the original atlas
gavoc.interfaceText: GAVOC provides two complementary views for exploring the database: a map-based geographical browser and a table-based detailed view. Both interfaces support full-text search and category filtering.
gavoc.screenshotDesc: Map and table views with search functionality
gavoc.step1Text: Navigate to the GAVOC page and locate the search box at the top. Enter either a historical Dutch/Portuguese name or a modern place name. The search is case-insensitive and searches across both original and present name fields.
gavoc.step2Text: Use the category dropdown to filter results by location type. This narrows down results when searching common terms or exploring specific types of places.
gavoc.step3Text: Results appear immediately on the interactive map. Clustered markers group nearby locations. Click clusters to zoom in, or click individual markers to view place details including historical context and modern location.
gavoc.step4Text: Switch to the Table tab to view structured data. The table shows all metadata fields including map grid references, page numbers from the original atlas, and precise coordinates. Click any row to highlight the location on the map.
gavoc.searchResultsDesc: Map view with clustered markers and popup details
gavoc.nameVariationsText: The Thesaurus tab reveals how place names evolved over time and across different cartographic traditions. It shows relationships between Dutch, Portuguese, and local Malayalam toponyms.
gavoc.nameVariationsExample: The place "Cochin" appears with variants like "Cochim", "Cotchym", and "Kochi", showing orthographic variations and modern standardisation.
gavoc.semanticText: The thesaurus connects related places through hierarchical and associative relationships. Settlements are linked to their surrounding regions, ports to their associated bays, and historical administrative units to modern equivalents.
gavoc.accessingText: Each place in GAVOC has a unique, persistent URI that can be used in scholarly citations, linked data applications, and external research projects. Click on any place detail to view its URI.
gavoc.linkingText: Use GAVOC URIs in your own research database, digital edition, or web application. The persistent identifiers ensure long-term stability and enable integration with the broader GLOBALISE infrastructure.
gavoc.apiText: Programmatically access GAVOC data through the public API. Query by name, category, or geographic bounding box. Results are returned in JSON format for easy integration into your workflows.
gavoc.apiReturns: Returns: JSON with place details, coordinates, and metadata
gavoc.osmText: Standard street map view showing modern roads, settlements, and geographic features for contextualising historical locations.
gavoc.satelliteText: Aerial imagery overlay providing visual context for coastal features, river systems, and topographical relationships.
gavoc.terrainText: Topographic display highlighting elevation changes, important for understanding defensive positions and trade routes.
gavoc.clusteringText: Automatic grouping of nearby locations for clarity at different zoom levels, preventing marker overlap.
gavoc.integrationIntro: GAVOC serves as the reference dataset for the entire Necessary Reunions project, providing authoritative place name data for:
gavoc.rechartedLinking: re:Charted Linking Annotations: When creating geotagging annotations in the map viewer, GAVOC provides the target locations with persistent identifiers.
gavoc.gazetteerSearch: Gazetteer Search: The Gazetteer tool queries GAVOC data to show which historical maps contain specific places.
gavoc.externalResearch: External Research Projects: The public API enables integration with digital editions, databases, and web applications beyond this project.

gazetteer.heading: Gazetteer: Place Search Interface
gazetteer.intro: The Gazetteer provides a streamlined search interface for exploring places located on the 30 maps available in re:Charted. It collects linked and geotagged places from map annotations, building comprehensive place biographies that show the history and transitions of locations in Kerala across different sources and time periods.
gazetteer.coreConceptText: The Gazetteer aggregates all geotagged annotations from the 30 historical maps in re:Charted, creating a searchable database of places that appear across the collection. Unlike GAVOC, which provides comprehensive historical place name data for the entire Kerala region, the Gazetteer focuses specifically on places that have been annotated and linked on the maps in this project.
gazetteer.mapCentric: Map-Centric: Every entry is directly linked to one or more historical maps where the place appears
gazetteer.annotationBased: Annotation-Based: Places are derived from linking annotations that connect map features to geographic locations
gazetteer.contextual: Contextual: Shows how often and in what context each place appears across the map collection
gazetteer.biographical: Biographical: Builds a place biography by aggregating information from multiple maps and time periods
gazetteer.videoDesc: Learn how to search for places and navigate the Gazetteer interface
gazetteer.listViewIntro: The default list view displays all places in the Gazetteer as a searchable table. Each entry shows:
gazetteer.placeName: Place Name: The standardised modern name of the location
gazetteer.variants: Historical Variants: Alternative names found on the historical maps
gazetteer.mapCount: Map Count: Number of maps in the collection where this place appears
gazetteer.classificationList: Classification: Category or type of place (settlement, fort, port, etc.)
gazetteer.mapViewIntro: Switch to map view to see all Gazetteer places plotted on a modern base map. This geographic visualisation helps you:
gazetteer.spatial: Understand the spatial distribution of annotated places
gazetteer.clusters: Identify clusters of frequently mapped locations along the coast or inland
gazetteer.relationships: Explore geographic relationships between places in the collection
gazetteer.clickMarkers: Click on map markers to view place details and linked maps
gazetteer.searchIntro: The Gazetteer supports flexible search across both modern and historical place names:
gazetteer.modernNameText: Search using contemporary place names like "Kochi" or "Kannur" to find how these locations appear on historical maps.
gazetteer.historicalNameText: Search using VOC-era names like "Cochin" or "Cananoor" to discover which maps include these historical toponyms.
gazetteer.partialText: Use partial search terms to find variations and similar names across the collection.
gazetteer.detailedIntro: Click on any place in the Gazetteer to view its detailed page, which aggregates information from all maps where the place appears.
gazetteer.detailedVideoDesc: Navigate detailed place pages and discover linked maps and annotations
gazetteer.overviewIntro: The top section of each place page provides essential information:
gazetteer.primaryName: Primary Name: The standardised modern name used as the main identifier
gazetteer.geoCoordinates: Geographic Coordinates: Latitude and longitude of the location
gazetteer.modernMap: Modern Map: Interactive map showing the present-day location
gazetteer.quickStats: Quick Stats: Number of maps featuring this place and total annotations
gazetteer.nameVariantsIntro: The Gazetteer displays all name variations found across the map annotations, showing:
gazetteer.spellings: Historical Spellings: Different orthographic variants used in VOC-era maps
gazetteer.languages: Language Variations: Names in Dutch, Portuguese, and local languages
gazetteer.classifications: Classifications: Categories assigned to the place (settlement, fort, port, river, etc.)
gazetteer.sourceAttrib: Source Attribution: Which maps contain each name variant
gazetteer.linksIntro: Each place page shows all maps where the location appears, providing direct navigation to view the place in its historical cartographic context:
gazetteer.thumbnails: Map Thumbnails: Visual previews of each map featuring the place
gazetteer.mapMetadata: Map Metadata: Title, date, and source information for each map
gazetteer.directLinks: Direct Links: Click to open the map in re:Charted with the place annotation highlighted
gazetteer.annotationDetails: Annotation Details: View the specific iconography or text annotations linked to this place
gazetteer.frequencyIntro: The Gazetteer analyses how often and in what contexts each place appears across the map collection:
gazetteer.temporal: Temporal Distribution: Timeline showing when the place appears on maps across different decades
gazetteer.coverage: Map Coverage: Percentage of the collection that includes this place
gazetteer.annotationTypes: Annotation Types: Breakdown of how the place is represented (iconography, text labels, fortification symbols)
gazetteer.prominence: Cartographic Prominence: Analysis of how prominently the place is featured on different maps
gazetteer.biographiesIntro: By aggregating information across multiple maps and time periods, the Gazetteer constructs a "biography" for each place showing:
gazetteer.nameEvolution: Name Evolution: How the place name changed or was standardised over time
gazetteer.functionalChanges: Functional Changes: Shifts in classification (e.g., from settlement to fortified port)
gazetteer.cartoAttention: Cartographic Attention: Periods when the place received more or less detailed representation
gazetteer.geoContext: Geographic Context: How the place's relationship to nearby features was depicted across different maps
gazetteer.integrationIntro: The Gazetteer acts as a bridge between GAVOC's comprehensive historical database and re:Charted's visual map interface:
gazetteer.gavocConnection: GAVOC Connection: Places in the Gazetteer link to their GAVOC entries for additional historical and geographic context
gazetteer.rechartedIntegration: re:Charted Integration: Click through from Gazetteer to view any place on its original historical map with full annotation context
gazetteer.crossReference: Cross-Reference: Use the Gazetteer to discover which GAVOC places appear on which maps, and which maps contain annotations for specific locations
gazetteer.workflowHeading: Workflow: From Search to Visual Analysis
gazetteer.workflowStep1: Search for a place in the Gazetteer using modern or historical names
gazetteer.workflowStep2: Review the place page to see frequency, name variants, and map coverage
gazetteer.workflowStep3: Click on a specific map to open it in re:Charted viewer
gazetteer.workflowStep4: Explore the annotation in visual context with surrounding features
gazetteer.workflowStep5: Use linking annotations to discover related places and iconography
gazetteer.workflowStep6: Cross-reference with GAVOC for broader historical and geographic context

api.heading: API Documentation
api.intro: The Necessary Reunions project provides public APIs for accessing place name data and integrating with external research projects and datasets.
api.gavocIntro: The GAVOC API provides programmatic access to the historical place name database, allowing you to query locations and retrieve their historical and modern names, coordinates, and categories.
api.gavocEndpoint: Retrieve a list of places with optional filtering
api.gazetteerIntro: Access places from the Gazetteer database, which contains all locations annotated on the 30 maps in re:Charted.
api.gazetteerEndpoint: Search places in the gazetteer database
api.iiifIntro: All maps are served using the IIIF (International Image Interoperability Framework) protocol, allowing integration with any IIIF-compatible viewer or application.
api.iiifEndpoint: Access the main IIIF collection manifest
api.rateLimitText: The APIs are freely accessible for research purposes. Please be considerate with request volume. For large-scale data access, consider downloading the full datasets from GitHub.

developers.heading: For Developers
developers.intro: The Necessary Reunions codebase is open source and available on GitHub. This section provides technical details for developers who want to run the project locally, contribute, or adapt it for their own research.
developers.availableAt: The application will be available at
developers.iiifFirstText: The application is built around the International Image Interoperability Framework (IIIF) for handling historical maps and manuscripts. All images are served via IIIF Image API, and metadata follows the IIIF Presentation API specification.
developers.multiLayerIntro: Four distinct annotation types with different data sources:
developers.localAnno: Local: User-created annotations with full CRUD operations
developers.georeferencingAnno: Georeferencing: Generated during manifest creation for map overlay
developers.resilienceText: Critical anti-pattern prevention for external service failures. All external API calls use timeout controllers with graceful fallbacks to prevent UI crashes.
developers.pythonIntro: The data/scripts/ directory contains Python pipelines for:
developers.makeManifest: make_manifest.py: Generate IIIF manifests from CSV data
developers.adaptingIntro: To adapt this codebase for your own historical map project:
developers.adaptStep1: Prepare your images: Convert your historical maps to IIIF-compatible format
developers.adaptStep2: Create manifests: Use the make_manifest.py script as a template
developers.adaptStep3: Set up AnnoRepo: Configure your own AnnoRepo container for annotations
developers.adaptStep4: Customise the UI: Update branding, colours, and text in the components
developers.adaptStep5: Deploy: Use Netlify, Vercel, or your preferred hosting platform

contributing.heading: Contributing
contributing.intro: Contributions to the Necessary Reunions project are welcome. Whether you're fixing bugs, improving documentation, or proposing new features, your input helps advance digital humanities research.
contributing.issuesIntro: If you encounter bugs or have feature requests, <link>open an issue on GitHub</link>. Include:
contributing.issueDesc: Clear description of the problem or suggestion
contributing.prText: To contribute code changes, fork the repository, create a branch, make your changes, and submit a pull request. The project uses automated linting and formatting (ESLint and Prettier).
contributing.contactIntro: For questions about the project or collaboration opportunities, contact:
contributing.leon: Leon van Wissen - Technical Lead (University of Amsterdam)
contributing.acknowledgementsText: This project is funded by the NWO XS grant (March-December 2025) and conducted at the Huygens Institute. It builds upon the broader <link>GLOBALISE project</link>, which aims to unlock the archives of the Dutch East India Company for researchers worldwide.
